title: Kathy Castor
deleted: ==Political campaigns==

Castor entered the race for what was then the 11th district when five-term Democrat [[Jim Davis (Florida politician)|Jim Davis]] (D) chose to run for governor (he lost to [[Charlie Crist]] in November).

Castor won the September 5, 2006 Democratic primary—the real contest in what has long been the only safe Democratic district on Florida's Gulf Coast—defeating State Senator [[Les Miller (Florida politician)|Les Miller]], Al Fox, Scott Farrell, and Michael Steinberg. She received 54% of the vote, a full 20 points ahead of Miller in the five-way race.

Eddie Adams Jr., an architect and former hospital laboratory technologist,<ref>{{cite web|title=Homepage|url=http://adamsforcongress.org/|publisher=Eddie Adams, Jr. for U.S. Congress|access-date=April 19, 2014|archive-date=February 19, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219032339/http://www.adamsforcongress.org/|url-status=live}}</ref> was the only [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to file.  Castor was endorsed by the pro-choice political action committee [[EMILY's List]], the League of Conservation Voters, Oceans Champions, The Tampa Tribune, The St. Petersburg Times and The Bradenton Herald.

Castor handily won the 2006 November general election, 70% to 30%--becoming the first woman to represent the Tampa Bay area in Congress, as well as only the third person to represent this Tampa-based district since its creation in 1963 (it was the 10th district from 1963 to 1967, the 6th from 1967 to 1973, the 7th from 1973 to 1993, the 11th from 1993 to 2013, and has been the 14th since 2013).
Castor was reelected in November 2008 71% to 29% in a rematch with Adams.

Castor was challenged by Republican nominee Mike Prendergast, a career military officer who retired in 2008 as a [[colonel]] in the [[United States Army]]. Castor was reelected in November 2010 with 60% of the vote to Prendergast's 40%. Though Castor won convincingly, it was still the best showing for a Republican in this district since 1994.

After the 2010 census, Florida gained two more congressional seats. As a result, Castor's district was renumbered as the 14th. It was no less Democratic than its predecessor, and Castor won reelection with 70.2 percent of the vote over Republican E. J. Otero.
No candidates filed to oppose Castor in the 2014 election.

Mike Prendergast considered a rematch against Castor in 2016, but instead opted to run for sheriff of [[Citrus County, Florida|Citrus County]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/story/kathy-castor-has-easier-path-reelection-mike-prendergast-out-picture|title=Kathy Castor's Re-election Path Clearer After Prendergast Withdraws|date=2016-03-30|work=Sunshine State News {{!}} Florida Political News|access-date=2017-09-14|language=en|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210727/http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/story/kathy-castor-has-easier-path-reelection-mike-prendergast-out-picture|url-status=live}}</ref> Christine Quinn, the founder of My Family Seasonings, challenged Castor in the 2016 election, running on a pro-business and anti-immigration platform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://floridapolitics.com/archives/216131-meet-christine-quinn-woman-wants-take-away-kathy-castors-job|title=Meet Christine Quinn, the woman who wants to take Kathy Castor's job in Congress – Florida Politics|website=floridapolitics.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-14|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210758/https://floridapolitics.com/archives/216131-meet-christine-quinn-woman-wants-take-away-kathy-castors-job|url-status=live}}</ref> A court-ordered redistricting cut out the district's share of St. Petersburg while pushing it further into Tampa. However, it was no less Democratic than its predecessor, and Castor held her seat against Quinn, with 61.79% of the vote to Quinn's 38.21%.

title: Kathy Castor
deleted: ==Political positions==
===Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (Bailout Bill)===

Castor was the only Democratic member of Congress from Florida to vote against the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, also known as the "bailout bill," stating that:  "After thoughtful consideration and review, I voted against President Bush's $700 billion bailout. The Bush plan does not provide sufficient help to middle-class families in the housing squeeze or taxpayer protections."<ref>{{cite web|title=Castor says she was only (Florida) Democrat to vote against the Wall Street bailout.|url=http://www.politifact.com/florida/statements/2010/mar/25/kathy-castor/castor-says-she-was-only-democrat-tarp/|publisher=PolitiFact Florida|access-date=April 19, 2014|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210732/https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2010/mar/25/kathy-castor/castor-says-she-was-only-democrat-tarp/|url-status=live}}</ref> Instead, she championed programs such as the Neighborhood Stabilization Program<ref>{{cite news|last=Hinman|first=Michael|title=Neighborhood Stabilization Program needs beefing up, critics say|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/stories/2008/11/24/story10.html?page=all|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=Tampa Bay Business Journal|date=November 24, 2008|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210727/https://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/stories/2008/11/24/story10.html?page=all|url-status=live}}</ref> and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, and said it was "the lifeline that really saved the economy."<ref>{{cite news|last=Perry|first=Mitch|title=In Tiger Bay speech, Kathy Castor says she understands the rise of the Tea Party|url=http://cltampa.com/politicalanimal/archives/2014/03/07/in-tiger-bay-speech-kathy-castor-says-she-understands-the-rise-of-the-tea-party#.Ux25KM67Ttk|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=Creative Loafing|date=March 7, 2014|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210742/https://www.cltampa.com/news-views/article/20756744/in-tiger-bay-speech-kathy-castor-says-she-understands-the-rise-of-the-tea-party#.Ux25KM67Ttk|url-status=live}}</ref> In Tampa Bay, Recovery Act funds were invested in transportation, education, housing, research, law enforcement and various local infrastructure improvements.<ref>{{cite web|title=What does the Recovery Act Mean for Tampa Bay|url=http://castor.house.gov/homepage/recoverytampabay.htm|publisher=Representative Kathy Castor|access-date=April 19, 2014|archive-date=May 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502082915/http://castor.house.gov/homepage/recoverytampabay.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> The I-4/Crosstown Connector received the largest Recovery Act investment in Tampa Bay, with $105 million to make the completion of the project possible and it opened to the public in 2014.
===Iraq War===

Since her first congressional campaign in 2006, Castor has supported a withdrawal of U.S. troops out of Iraq and redeployment of U.S. troops from Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite news|last=Van Sickler|first=Michael|title=Castor tops GOP opponent|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/11/08/Hillsborough/Castor_tops_GOP_oppon.shtml|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=The Tampa Bay Times|date=November 8, 2006|archive-date=April 18, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418233643/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/11/08/Hillsborough/Castor_tops_GOP_oppon.shtml|url-status=live}}</ref> Her first committee assignment was the House Armed Services. In 2007, Castor voted to redeploy U.S. troops out of Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kathy Castor on War & Peace|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/FL/Kathy_Castor_War_+_Peace.htm|publisher=On The Issues|access-date=April 19, 2014|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210748/https://www.ontheissues.org/FL/Kathy_Castor_War_+_Peace.htm|url-status=live}}</ref>
===Education===

Castor has called the GI Bill for the 21st Century that passed in 2008 despite strenuous opposition by President Bush "one of the most important pieces of legislation that I have cosponsored."<ref name=audioboo>{{cite web |title=Congresswoman Kathy Castor at Suncoast Tiger Bay Club St. Petersburg 3-7-14 |url=https://audioboo.fm/boos/1975550-congresswoman-kathy-castor-at-suncoast-tiger-bay-club-st-petersburg-3-7-14 |publisher=AudioBoo Ltd. |access-date=June 16, 2015 |archive-date=April 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419015853/https://audioboo.fm/boos/1975550-congresswoman-kathy-castor-at-suncoast-tiger-bay-club-st-petersburg-3-7-14 |url-status=live }}</ref>  The bill restored full, four-year college scholarships to veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars from benefits at the time that were only paying about 70 percent of a public college education and 30 percent of a private college education for returning veterans. The legislation also allowed veterans to transfer those benefits to family members.

Castor was outspoken on the cuts that the 2013 Republican sequester would create for [[Head Start Program|Head Start]] programs as well as research programs at Moffitt Cancer Care and University of South Florida.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://castor.house.gov/UploadedFiles/sequestration13.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 1, 2015 |archive-date=December 6, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141206070602/http://castor.house.gov/uploadedfiles/sequestration13.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2014, she supported a bipartisan budget agreement that included restoring Head Start funding with an increase of $1 billion over the sequester level and $612 million over the 2013 enacted level.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tbo.com/pinellas-county/in-pinellas-head-start-starts-again-20140824/|title=In Pinellas, Head Start starts again|date=2014-08-24|work=TBO.com|access-date=2018-07-26|archive-date=December 20, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220101809/http://www.tbo.com/pinellas-county/in-pinellas-head-start-starts-again-20140824/|url-status=live}}</ref>
===Health care===

Castor has been interested in health care since her first elected position on the Hillsborough County Commission, where she defended the need to fund the county's indigent health care plan.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}} In 2008, Castor successfully championed legislation to allow low-income families with overdue medical bills to still be eligible for student loans.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}} Kathy Castor has served on the House Energy & Commerce Committee since 111th Congress.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kathy Castor (D-Fla.)|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/kathy-castor-d-fla/gIQAEoCLAP_topic.html#path-to-power|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210738/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/#path-to-power|url-status=live}}</ref> During her membership in the Health Subcommittee, the subcommittee worked toward progressive reform for Florida families, businesses, and university medical and nursing colleges {{Citation needed|date=December 2018}}. Since the Affordable Care Act passed, Castor has worked to educate Floridians about new patient protections and rights, and about enrollment in the marketplace exchange.<ref>{{cite news|last=McNeill|first=Claire|title=U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor preaches benefits of new health care law|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/health/us-rep-kathy-castor-preaches-benefits-of-new-health-care-law/2135510|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=The Tampa Bay Times|date=August 8, 2013|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210740/https://www.tampabay.com/news/health/us-rep-kathy-castor-preaches-benefits-of-new-health-care-law/2135510/|url-status=live}}</ref> She has been critical of Gov. Rick Scott and the Republican-led Florida Legislature for not accepting more than $50 billion in federal funding to expand Medicaid to provide health care access to more than 1 million Floridians.<ref>{{cite news|last=Moorhead|first=Molly|title=U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor to Gov. Rick Scott: Veto the budget, call lawmakers back to expand Medicaid|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/us-rep-kathy-castor-to-gov-rick-scott-veto-the-budget-call-lawmakers-back/2118807|access-date=April 19, 2014|newspaper=The Tampa Bay Times|date=May 2, 2013|archive-date=April 19, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419025108/http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/us-rep-kathy-castor-to-gov-rick-scott-veto-the-budget-call-lawmakers-back/2118807|url-status=live}}</ref> With the assistance of the National Association of Children's Hospitals, she and Rep. Dave Reichert of Washington founded the bipartisan Children's Health Care Caucus, dedicated to improving quality of health care and health care access for children {{Citation needed|date=December 2018}}.
===Comprehensive immigration reform===

Castor supports comprehensive immigration reform.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cltampa.com/dailyloaf/archives/2013/02/11/pushing-immigration-reform-kathy-castor-invites-jose-godinez-samperio-to-the-state-of-the-union-address#.URo-P_H-DeY|title=Pushing immigration reform, Kathy Castor invites Jose Godinez-Samperio to the State of the Union address|work=Creative Loafing: Tampa Bay|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210726/https://www.cltampa.com/news-views/article/20752847/pushing-immigration-reform-kathy-castor-invites-jose-godinez-samperio-to-the-state-of-the-union-address#.URo-P_H-DeY|url-status=live}}</ref> Castor applauded President Obama announcement in November 2014 on immigration accountability executive action.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=397811|title=U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor's statement on President's Immigration Accountability Executive Actions|date=2014-11-20|website=Representative Kathy Castor|access-date=2018-07-26|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210725/https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=397811|url-status=live}}</ref>
===LGBT rights===

Castor supports same sex marriage. In 2005, while serving on the Hillsborough County Commission, she was the lone commissioner to vote against a resolution to ban gay pride activities and events. In 2013, the Hillsborough County Commission unanimously reversed its position on the gay pride ban.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/public-hearing-under-way-over-hillsborough-county-ban-on-acknowledging-gay/2124940|title=Hillsborough County Commission unanimously repeals ban of gay pride recognition|date=2013-06-05|access-date=2018-07-26|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210758/https://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/public-hearing-under-way-over-hillsborough-county-ban-on-acknowledging-gay/2124940/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2013, she filed a historic Amicus Brief in support of the Supreme Court striking down Section 3 of the defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and applauded the Supreme Court when it made its ruling to do so later that year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=340593|title=Statement by U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor on DOMA ruling|date=2013-06-26|website=Representative Kathy Castor|access-date=2018-07-26|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210736/https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=340593|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2019, Castor co-sponsored and voted for the [[Equality Act (United States)|Equality Act]] which would amend the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|Civil Rights Act]] to "prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or pregnancy, childbirth, or a related medical condition of an individual, as well as because of sex-based stereotypes."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/5/text/eh|title=Text - H.R.5 - 116th Congress (2019-2020): Equality Act|last=Cicilline|first=David N.|date=2019-05-20|website=www.congress.gov|access-date=2019-10-09|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210746/https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/5/text/eh|url-status=live}}</ref>
===U.S.–Cuba relations===

Castor supports normalizing relations between the United States and Cuba. She visited the island in April 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cltampa.com/politicalanimal/archives/2015/05/29/with-cuba-off-terror-list-rep-castor-calls-for-tampa-embassy#.VWyzDM9Viko|title=With Cuba off terror list, Rep. Castor calls for Tampa embassy|work=Creative Loafing: Tampa Bay|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210740/https://www.cltampa.com/news-views/article/20761673/with-cuba-off-terror-list-rep-castor-calls-for-tampa-embassy#.VWyzDM9Viko|url-status=live}}</ref>
===Gun policy===
Castor is an outspoken advocate for gun control.

Following the 2016 [[Orlando nightclub shooting|Pulse nightclub shooting]], Castor participated in [[John Lewis's]] [[2016 United States House of Representatives sit-in|Congressional sit-in]] to demand that those on the [[No Fly List]] lose the right to purchase firearms.<ref name="Castor 2016">{{cite web| url=https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398192| title=U.S. Rep. Castor joins today's sit-in protest to demand a vote on gun safety| date=22 June 2016| website=U. S. Representative Kathy Castor| publisher=U. S. Federal Government| access-date=5 March 2018| archive-date=November 18, 2020| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210741/https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398192| url-status=live}}</ref>

Castor has spoken about her perception of Florida's lacking gun legislation, saying, "My home state of Florida has some of the weakest gun laws; we lack expanded background checks that would prevent individuals on the terrorist watch list, criminals, domestic abusers and the dangerously mentally ill from purchasing guns."<ref name="Castor 2016"/>
She supports a ban of [[high-capacity magazine ban|high-capacity magazines]], as well as reinstating the [[Federal Assault Weapons Ban]].<ref name="Castor 2016"/>

While she acknowledged that preventing those on the No-Fly List from buying guns or banning assault rifles might not have prevented the Pulse nightclub shooting, she stated, "if we could stop another tragedy. . .I think it's reasonable to say, here are a couple of common sense laws we could pass to make Americans more safe."<ref name="Marrero 2016">{{cite news| url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/publicsafety/crime/after-orlando-massacre-us-rep-kathy-castor-calls-for-renewal-of-assault/2281500| work=Tampa Bay Times| location=St. Petersburg, Florida| title=After Orlando massacre, U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor calls for renewal of assault weapons ban| last=Marrero| first=Tony| date=13 June 2016| access-date=5 March 2018| archive-date=November 18, 2020| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210803/https://www.tampabay.com/news/publicsafety/crime/after-orlando-massacre-us-rep-kathy-castor-calls-for-renewal-of-assault/2281500/| url-status=live}}</ref>

In the wake of the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]], Castor reiterated her support for repealing the [[Dickey Amendment]] of 1996, which discourages funding to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] to research gun violence prevention.<ref name="Castor 2018">{{cite web| url=https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398600| title=U.S. Rep. Castor's Statement on Gun Violence Prevention at the CDC| website=U. S. Representative Kathy Castor| publisher=U. S. Federal Government| date=16 February 2018| access-date=5 March 2018| archive-date=November 18, 2020| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210738/https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398600| url-status=live}}</ref>
===Impeachment of Donald Trump===

On December 18, 2019, Castor voted to impeach President [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-impeachment-vote-results-house-2019-12 |title=Archived copy |access-date=January 22, 2020 |archive-date=December 24, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191224170114/https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-impeachment-vote-results-house-2019-12 |url-status=live }}</ref>
